source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: Five different thermochemically treated Zircaloy-2 cladding tubes with known boiling water reactor (BWR) corrosion properties are examined

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: particles in the range of 50 to 5000 A are analyzed

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: the oxidation rate (oxide thickness) is an increasing function of particle size

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: the oxidation rate is an increasing function of the ratio of the number of particles with the hexagonal close packed (hcp) structure to the total number of chromium-bearing particles

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: The beta-quenched claddings with a high degree of supersaturation of low-soluble alloying elements indicates small oxide weight gains

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: the nonquenched claddings with a low degree of supersaturation show large oxide weight gains

STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: For SEM analysis—prepared by mechanical grinding and subsequent etching in a HF:HNO3:H2O solution to expose the second-phase particles.
process_step: mechanical grinding; etching in HF:HNO3:H2O solution

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: For STEM and ED analysis—prepared by electropolishing in a perchloric and acetic acid solution in order to obtain thin foil samples.
process_step: electropolishing in perchloric and acetic acid solution

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: For EDS analysis—prepared as in (1) above to let the second-phase particles stand out from the matrix. However, after the etching a zirconium oxide film (replica) was deposited and the remaining matrix was dissolved with the same etching solution as mentioned above.
process_step: etching in HF:HNO3:H2O solution; replica deposition; matrix dissolution

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: The replicas utilized in the EDS analysis included particles in the range of 50 to 6000 A.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: More than 200 different particles in these replicas were analyzed to determine their chemical compositions.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: The replica can provide a more accurate determination of the chemical composition of the second-phase particles than the thin foil.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: By counting particles of different sizes on the SEM and STEM micrographs, the average particle size distribution is determined for each tube type (Fig. 1).

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: By comparing these plots the claddings can be classified into three groups. The first group is represented by claddings with a preponderance of large particles ((a) and (b) claddings), the second group of claddings mainly contains very small particles ((d) and (e) claddings), and the third group is represented by the (c) cladding with a preponderance of intermediate size particles.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk4
evidence_span: In claddings ( b ) and ( c ) (Fig. 6) the low zirconium content peak represents Zr (Cr,Fe) particles nucleated on Zr (Ni,Fe) particles where the former have hcp structure

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk4
evidence_span: The high zirconium content peak represents discrete chromium-bearing particles where ED analysis showed that they are of the fcc type

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk4
evidence_span: These two crystallographically distinct particles also show significant differences in their Cr/Fe ratios: the fcc type has a considerably lower value than the hcp type

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk4
evidence_span: Claddings ( d ) and ( e ) , which are beta-quenched (Table 1), contain a large amount of chromium-bearing particles; 99% of these are of the discrete fcc type and 1% are of the hcp type nucleated on Zr (Ni,Fe) particles

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk4
evidence_span: Claddings ( d ) and ( e ) , which are beta-quenched (Table 1), contain a large amount of chromium-bearing particles; 99% of these are of the discrete fcc type and 1% are of the hcp type nucleated on Zr (Ni,Fe) particles

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk4
evidence_span: In claddings ( c ) and ( b ) the corresponding percentage of the hcp type of particles are 45% and 60% , respectively

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk4
evidence_span: In claddings ( c ) and ( b ) the corresponding percentage of the hcp type of particles are 45% and 60% , respectively

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_027_chunk4
evidence_span: In cladding ( a ) the chemical composition of the discrete chromium-bearing particles is approximately equal to that of the chromium-bearing particles nucleated on the nickel-bearing particles. This indicates that all Zr (Cr,Fe) particles present in cladding ( a ) are of the hcp type
